block.p: First Bank System Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings jumped 84 percent, while its operating profits advanced 21 percent, paced by rising fee revenue from its trust and corporate payment systems units.
The company said its net income totaled $254.1 million, or $1.81 a share, up from $137.9 million, or $1 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

First Bank System Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings jumped 84 percent, while its operating profits advanced 21 percent, paced by rising fee revenue from its trust and corporate payment systems units.
The company said its net income totaled $254.1 million, or $1.81 a share, up from $137.9 million, or $1 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.
First Bank said that it had $87 million, or 61 cents a share, in one-time gains in the quarter, and that its profits from operations totaled $167.1 million, or $1.18 a share.
The operating profits matched the average forecast in a Zacks Investment Research survey of 24 analysts.

The gains were partly a result of First Interstate Bancorp's decision to back out of an agreement to be bought by First Bank, which is based in Minneapolis. As such, First Bank received a $200 million pretax breakup fee from Wells Fargo & Company, the eventual buyer of First Interstate, that included $75 million in the second quarter.
First Bank also listed a $65 million state income tax refund and $400,000 in securities gains as pretax items.
Noninterest income, including fees, provided most of the earnings improvement, rising 16 percent, to $219.5 million.
Net interest income -- the interest First Bank earned minus the interest it paid -- rose 7.9 percent from a year earlier, to $391.8 million.
First Bank set aside $35 million for expected loan losses, up from $27 million a year earlier.
Noninterest expenses, mostly salaries, rose only 1 percent, to $306.2 million.

First Bank, the 25th-biggest United States bank at the end of the first quarter, had $36.2 billion in assets at the end of June, an 8.2 percent increase from a year earlier. It has 384 branches in 11 states.
